content: quote: NORAD, the high-tech facility responsible for monitoring the skies over North America, faces continuing security problems at its new location inside an office building on Peterson Air Force Base in Colorado Springs, Colo. An internal document summarizing a recent security evaluation “recommends implementing difficult and costly retrofits and new construction to correct numerous physical vulnerabilities” to the building. Last year, the military completed a move of NORAD from a nuclear-hardened bunker burrowed into nearby Cheyenne Mountain to the basement of Building No. 2 at Peterson.(Washington Times, March 27, 2009, Pg. 11) This would be funny if it wasn’t so worrisome! It seems that the AF has been slipping in the last few years.....
quote: NORAD, the high-tech facility responsible for monitoring the skies over North America, faces continuing security problems at its new location inside an office building on Peterson Air Force Base in Colorado Springs, Colo. Last year, the military completed a move of NORAD from a nuclear-hardened bunker burrowed into nearby Cheyenne Mountain to the basement of Building No. 2 at Peterson.(Washington Times, March 27, 2009, Pg. 11)

content: quote: Originally posted by Knele: quote: NORAD, the high-tech facility responsible for monitoring the skies over North America, faces continuing security problems at its new location inside an office building on Peterson Air Force Base in Colorado Springs, Colo. An internal document summarizing a recent security evaluation “recommends implementing difficult and costly retrofits and new construction to correct numerous physical vulnerabilities” to the building. Last year, the military completed a move of NORAD from a nuclear-hardened bunker burrowed into nearby Cheyenne Mountain to the basement of Building No. 2 at Peterson.(Washington Times, March 27, 2009, Pg. 11) This would be funny if it wasn’t so worrisome! It seems that the AF has been slipping in the last few years..... Cheyenne Mountain went into caretaker status over a year ago (not that I agree with it). That the building they moved into would need renovation is not a surprise. I know the type of renovastion the report refers to and frequently it is required when one acency or division moves into a building whose previous occupants had lower security requirements. If need be and world events dictated it, the mountain could be reoccupied.

content: I have no idea why they moved out of Cheyenne Mountain, besides the cost savings factor. Leave it to the Air Force to cut costs when dealing with a nuclear threat. I worked in the mountain in 2005-06, and the command center had just gone through millions of dollars of renovation. I would go in there 2 or 3 times a shift and it was really well done. The Air Force didn't take care of those of that worked there anyway. They shut down the dining facility, and it was taken over by a contractor as more of a fast food place. It would cost 5 or 6 dollars to get a burger and fries, compared to what should be $2.40 in a DFAC. There were no MPF services in the mountain, only at Peterson. Well Petersons MPF hours went to 0900-1500 (to accomadate PT and training), and considering it takes 30 minutes to go to Pete from the mountain that was a big chunk out of a work day and going on your way in or leaving wasn't an option because the desk jockeys couldn't be bothered to do PT before work.
reply: I have no idea why they moved out of Cheyenne Mountain, besides the cost savings factor. Leave it to the Air Force to cut costs when dealing with a nuclear threat. I worked in the mountain in 2005-06, and the command center had just gone through millions of dollars of renovation. I would go in there 2 or 3 times a shift and it was really well done. The Air Force didn't take care of those of that worked there anyway. They shut down the dining facility, and it was taken over by a contractor as more of a fast food place. It would cost 5 or 6 dollars to get a burger and fries, compared to what should be $2.40 in a DFAC. There were no MPF services in the mountain, only at Peterson. Well Petersons MPF hours went to 0900-1500 (to accomadate PT and training), and considering it takes 30 minutes to go to Pete from the mountain that was a big chunk out of a work day and going on your way in or leaving wasn't an option because the desk jockeys couldn't be bothered to do PT before work.
title: NORAD Move Raises Concerns

content: The Air Force is so much more like a business than a military operation. I have friends at Peterson and what's left of Cheyenne Mountain and they shake their heads in astonishment of the so-called "leadership" of the Air Farce. I'm so glad I got out when I did. Moving out of Cheyenne was moronic. I bet I know why the move was done... certain high ranking officers got cushy post-retirement jobs with the contractors who did the moving work and stuff. It's the same reason a retired 3-star is CEO of Colt... the M-4 is still used because of that cr@p.
